Identification.LongTitle: Motor Vehicle Restraint Systems and Booster Seats Safety Regulations

Provision.Text: Whereas, pursuant to subsection 11(3) of the Motor Vehicle Safety Acta, a copy of the proposed Motor Vehicle Restraint Systems and Booster Seats Safety Regulations, substantially in the annexed form, was published in the Canada Gazette, Part I, on October 10, 2009, and a reasonable opportunity was afforded to interested persons to make representations to the Minister of Transport with respect to the proposed Regulations;

Therefore, Her Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Transport pursuant to subsection 11(1) of the Motor Vehicle Safety Acta, hereby makes the annexed Motor Vehicle Restraint Systems and Booster Seats Safety Regulations.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: Act means the Motor Vehicle Safety Act. (Loi)
booster seat means a removable device designed to be used in a vehicle for seating a person whose mass is at least 18 kg, to ensure that the seat belt assembly fits properly. (siège d’appoint)
car bed means a restraint system for an infant with special needs that is designed to restrain the infant in a supine or prone position on a continuous flat surface. (lit d’auto)
child means a person whose mass is more than 10 kg and not more than 30 kg. (enfant)
CMVSS means Canada Motor Vehicle Safety Standard. (NSVAC)

custom restraint system for a disabled person means a restraint system, other than a mass-produced restraint system, designed for a specific disabled person. (ensemble de retenue sur mesure pour personne handicapée)

disabled person means a person, other than an infant with special needs, who, for orthopaedic reasons or because of the person’s build or other physical characteristics, is unable to use an infant restraint system, a child restraint system, a booster seat, a built-in device referred to in item 213.4 of Schedule III to the Motor Vehicle Safety Regulations, or a vehicle seat belt. (personne handicapée)
infant means a person who is unable to walk unassisted and whose mass is not more than 10 kg. (bébé)
infant with special needs means an infant who is unable to use an infant restraint system and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: who was born at less than 37 weeks’ gestation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whose mass at birth was less than 2.2 kg; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: who has special breathing needs. (bébé qui a des besoins spéciaux)

Definition.Text: lower connector system means a system consisting of two connectors that each fit inside a checking device having the envelope dimensions shown in Figure 9 of Schedule 7, that are attached to the lower part of a restraint system or booster seat in a manner that does not allow for their removal without the use of tools, and that allow the restraint system or booster seat to be securely attached to a lower universal anchorage system of a vehicle. (système d’attaches inférieures)

lower universal anchorage system means a device, other than a vehicle seat belt, that is designed to secure the lower portion of a restraint system or booster seat to a vehicle, and that transfers the load from the restraint system or booster seat and its occupant to the vehicle structure or a vehicle seat structure. (dispositif universel d’ancrages d’attaches inférieurs)
mass-produced means manufactured, in whatever quantity, using only standard or uniform parts. (fabriqué en série)

restraint system means a removable device designed to be used together with the seat of a vehicle in order to restraint an infant, an infant with special needs, a child or a disabled person, but does not include a booster seat or a vehicle seat belt. (ensemble de retenue)

seat orientation reference line or SORL means the horizontal line passing through the plane of symmetry of the standard seat assembly and passing through the Z point as shown in Figures 3 and 4 of Schedule 7. (ligne repère d’orientation du siège ou LROS)

standard seat assembly means the seat that is specified in the drawing package entitled Standard Seat Assembly Specifications for Motor Vehicle Restraint Systems and Booster Seats Safety Regulations Compliance Testing (January 1, 2010), published by the Department of Transport, and that has seat belt anchorage points and a lower universal anchorage system located as indicated in Figures 3 and 4 of Schedule 7, respectively. (siège normalisé)

tether strap means a device that is fitted with a tether strap hook and secured to the rigid structure of a restraint system or booster seat, and that transfers the load from the restraint system or booster seat and its occupant to the user-ready tether anchorage. (courroie d’attache)

tether strap hook means a device that is used to attach a tether strap to a user-ready tether anchorage and that has an interface profile shown in Figure 1 of Schedule 7 or, in the case of a device with integrated adjustment hardware, Figure 2 of Schedule 7. (crochet de la courroie d’attache)
torso means the portion of the body of an anthropomorphic test device or an occupant, excluding the thighs, that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when the device or occupant is seated in a restraint system other than a car bed or in a booster seat, lies between the top of the restraint system seating surface or booster seat seating surface and the top of the shoulders; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the device or occupant is seated in a car bed, lies between the top of the continuous flat surface of the car bed and the top of the shoulders. (torse)

Definition.Text: TSD 209 means Technical Standards Document No. 209, Seat Belt Assemblies, published by the Department of Transport, as amended from time to time. (DNT 209)
TSD 302 means Technical Standards Document No. 302, Flammability of Interior Materials, published by the Department of Transport, as amended from time to time. (DNT 302)

user-ready tether anchorage means a device that transfers the tether strap load from a restraint system or booster seat and its occupant to the vehicle structure or a vehicle seat structure, and that is designed to accept a tether strap hook directly, without requiring the installation of any other device. (ancrage d’attache prêt à utiliser)

Subsection.Text: In these Regulations, “classes of vehicles” refers to those classes of vehicles prescribed by section 4 of the Motor Vehicle Safety Regulations and set out in Schedule III to those Regulations.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Interpretation — restraint system or booster seat
Subsection.Text: For the purposes of these Regulations, a reference in TSD 209 to webbing, a belt buckle, a tether strap attachment or a related piece of adjustment hardware that is part of a Type 1 seat belt assembly is to be read as a reference to webbing, a belt buckle, a tether strap attachment or a related piece of adjustment hardware that is part of a restraint system or booster seat, as the case may be.
For the purposes these Regulations, the symbol set out in Schedule 2 is prescribed as the national safety mark.

For the purposes of subsection 3(2) of the Act, on application by a company, the Minister may, in the form set out in Schedule 1, authorize the company to apply the national safety mark to a restraint system or booster seat and to any accompanying documentation or any packaging.
A company that intends to apply the national safety mark to a restraint system or booster seat must apply to the Minister to obtain the authorization referred to in subsection (1.1).

A company that applies the national safety mark to a restraint system or booster seat must reproduce the national safety mark as shown in Schedule 2, including the following information, in the locations indicated in that schedule:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the authorization number assigned to the company by the Minister; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number or numbers of the CMVSS to which the restraint system or booster seat conforms, namely,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 213, in the case of a child restraint system,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 213.1, in the case of an infant restraint system,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: 213.2, in the case of a booster seat,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: 213.3, in the case of a mass-produced restraint system for disabled persons,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: 213.3, in the case of a custom restraint system for a disabled person that is designed to be used only in school buses, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: 213.5, in the case of a restraint system for infants with special needs.

Subsection.Text: The national safety mark must be at least 50 mm in diameter and be stitched onto the restraint system or booster seat, indelibly moulded into or onto it, or indelibly printed on a label affixed to it in a permanent manner.
The national safety mark must, when applied to a restraint system or booster seat, be fully visible.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Location of national safety mark — removable base
Subsection.Text: If a restraint system is manufactured with a removable base and the seating component of the restraint system is designed to be used in a vehicle with or without the base, the national safety mark must be applied to the seating component.

Section.Text: For the purposes of sections 4 and 5 of the Act, child restraint systems, infant restraint systems, booster seats, restraint systems for disabled persons and restraint systems for infants with special needs are prescribed classes of equipment.

Subsection.Text: Every child restraint system must conform to the applicable standards set out in Part 2, CMVSS 213 — Child Restraint Systems.
Every infant restraint system must conform to the applicable standards set out in Part 3, CMVSS 213.1 — Infant Restraint Systems.
Every booster seat must conform to the applicable standards set out in Part 4, CMVSS 213.2 — Booster Seats.
Every restraint system for disabled persons must conform to the applicable standards set out in Part 5, CMVSS 213.3 — Restraint Systems for Disabled Persons.
Every restraint system for infants with special needs must conform to the applicable standards set out in Part 6, CMVSS 213.5 — Restraint Systems for Infants with Special Needs.

Every restraint system that is designed to be used as more than one type of restraint system or as a restraint system and booster seat must conform to the standards set out in Parts 2 to 6 that are applicable to each type of restraint system or booster seat for which it is designed to be used.

Heading.TitleText: Restraint System and Booster Seat Information

Section.MarginalNote: No importation without national safety mark
Section.Text: A company must not import into Canada a restraint system other than a custom restraint system for a disabled person that is not designed to be used only in school buses, or a booster seat, unless the company has applied the national safety mark to the restraint system or booster seat.

Every restraint system or booster seat that is equipped with a lower connector system must bear the lower universal anchorage system symbol shown in Schedule 3, on a background of contrasting colour, on or near the lower connector system, and the symbol must be fully visible to a person installing the restraint system or booster seat when the restraint system or booster seat is positioned in the vehicle.

Subsection.Text: A company must maintain — for each restraint system or booster seat to which it applies the national safety mark or that it imports into Canada — the records referred to in paragraph 5(1)(g) of the Act and retain those records, in paper form or in readily readable electronic form, for a period of at least five years after the day on which the restraint system or booster seat is manufactured or imported.
If the records referred to in subsection (1) are maintained by a person on behalf of the company, the company must keep the name and address of the person.
On request in writing from an inspector, a company must send to that inspector a copy, in either official language, of the records referred to in subsection (1) within

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 30 working days after day on which the request is mailed; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the records must be translated, 45 working days after the day on which the request is mailed.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of maintaining the registration system referred to in paragraph 5(1)(h) of the Act, a company must provide to each person who purchases a restraint system or booster seat an information card, in both official languages, that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: permits the purchaser to provide to the company or to a duly authorized representative of the company, at no cost, the purchaser’s name, mailing address and email address, the model name and number of the restraint system or booster seat, the date of purchase and the date of manufacture; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: includes a safety message concerning the importance of providing the information.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Information to be included in registration system
Subsection.Text: The registration system maintained by a company in accordance with paragraph 5(1)(h) of the Act must consist of the information provided to the company under paragraph (1)(a), and that information must be used only for the purposes of paragraph 5(1)(h) of the Act.

The information in the registration system maintained by a company in relation to a restraint system or booster seat must be kept for at least five years after the day on which the restraint system or booster seat is purchased.

Section.Text: For the purposes of paragraph 5(1)(b) of the Act, a company that imports into Canada a restraint system or booster seat must make, at the nearest customs office that is open for business, a declaration signed by the company’s duly authorized representative that contains the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the manufacturer of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the company importing the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a statement from the manufacturer or its duly authorized representative that the restraint system or booster seat conforms to the prescribed standards applicable on the date of manufacture;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the model name and number of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the number of restraint systems and the number of booster seats imported at the same time; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the restraint system or booster seat was imported.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of paragraph 7(1)(a) of the Act, the prescribed purposes for which a restraint system or booster seat may be imported temporarily are the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: exhibition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: demonstration;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: evaluation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: testing; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: further manufacturing prior to export.

Subsection.Text: The declaration referred to in paragraph 7(1)(a) of the Act must be filed with the Minister, be signed by the person importing the restraint system or booster seat and contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the manufacturer of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the importer’s name, mailing address, telephone number, facsimile number and email address and, if the importer is a company, the contact information of a contact person at the company;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the make and the model name or number of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the restraint system or booster seat is to be presented for importation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the purpose for which the restraint system or booster seat is being imported and a statement that it will be used only for that purpose;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a statement indicating that the restraint system or booster seat will remain in Canada for a period of not more than one year or the period specified by the Minister, as applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a statement indicating that the restraint system or booster seat will be exported or destroyed before the end of the one-year period or the period specified by the Minister, as applicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: if the declaration is signed by a representative, a statement by the importer indicating that the representative is authorized to sign.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection 10(1) of the Act, a person, other than the first retail purchaser, who obtained a restraint system or booster seat from a company is a prescribed person.
A notice of defect that is required to be given under subsection 10(1) of the Act must be in writing, in either paper or electronic form, and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a notice given to the Minister, be in either official language; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a notice given to the current owner of the restraint system or booster seat or a prescribed person,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: be in the person’s official language of choice, if it is known, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: be in both official languages.

Subsection.Text: A company must give the notice of defect to the current owner of the restraint system or booster seat and to the prescribed person as soon as feasible, but not later than 60 days after the day on which the company gives the notice of defect to the Minister.
The notice of defect that is given to the Minister must contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the company’s name and its contact information for the purpose of correspondence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the manufacturer of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number, title or other identification that is assigned by the company to the notice;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for each restraint system or booster seat that may contain the defect, its model name and number, the prescribed class of equipment and any other information that is necessary to permit its identification;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the period during which the restraint systems or booster seats were manufactured;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated number of restraint systems or booster seats that could potentially contain the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated percentage of the restraint systems or booster seats referred to in paragraph (f) that contain the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the nature of the defect, including the causes and contributing factors, if known, and a description of the location of the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the systems or components of the restraint system or booster seat that may be affected by the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a chronology of the principal events that led to the determination of the existence of the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: all relevant information, including a summary of warranty claims, field reports and service reports, with their dates of receipt, that the company used to determine the existence of the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the safety risk to persons arising from the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the corrective measures to be taken in respect of the defect and how they are to be implemented;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: any precautions that may be taken to minimize the safety risk until the corrective measures are implemented; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated date on which the notice of defect will be sent to the current owner of the restraint system or booster seat and the estimated date on which the notice of defect will be sent to a prescribed person.

Subsection.Text: The company is not required to provide the Minister with the information referred to in paragraphs (4)(j), (k), (m) and (n) if it is not available on the day on which the notice is given but must provide that information as soon as it is available.
A notice of defect that is given to the current owner of the restraint system or booster seat must contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the company’s name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the model name and number of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the following statements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: “This notice is sent to you in accordance with the requirements of the Motor Vehicle Safety Act.”, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: “This is to inform you that your restraint system or booster seat may contain a defect that could affect the safety of a person.”;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the number, title or other identification that is assigned by the company to the notice;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the motor vehicle safety recall number that is issued by the Department of Transport;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the nature of the defect, including the causes, and a description of the location of the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the systems or components of the restraint system or booster seat that may be affected by the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: operating conditions or other factors that may cause a malfunction of the system or component of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the warning signs, if any, of any malfunction that could arise as a result of the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the safety risk to persons arising from the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the type of injury that may result from the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the corrective measures to be taken in respect of the defect and how they are to be implemented, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a general description of the work involved,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the estimated time required in order to take the corrective measures,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement that the company will cover the costs of the corrective measures or an estimate of the cost of the corrective measures to the current owner of the restraint system or booster seat, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: information identifying the persons who can implement the corrective measures; and

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: any precautions that may be taken to minimize the safety risk until the corrective measures are implemented.

Subsection.Text: The company is not required to provide the current owner with the information referred to in paragraph (6)(l) if it is not available on the day on which the notice is given but must provide that information

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as it is available; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at the same time as the company provides the information required under subsection 10.4(1) of the Act.

Subsection.Text: The words “SAFETY”, “RECALL”, “RAPPEL” and “SÉCURITÉ” are required to be clearly visible

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the envelope, or through a window of the envelope, in upper case and in a font size that is larger than the one used for the recipient’s address, if the notice of defect is given to the current owner in paper form; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the subject line of the communication, in upper case, if the notice of defect is given to the current owner in electronic form.

Subsection.Text: A notice of defect that is given to a prescribed person must contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the company’s name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for each restraint system or booster seat that may contain the defect, its model name and number and any other information that is necessary to permit its identification;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number, title or other identification that is assigned by the company to the notice;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the motor vehicle safety recall number issued by the Department of Transport;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the nature of the defect, including the causes, and a description of the location of the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: operating conditions or other factors that may cause a malfunction of the system or component of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the safety risk to persons arising from the defect;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the corrective measures to be taken in respect of the defect and how they are to be implemented; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any precautions that may be taken to minimize the safety risk until the corrective measures are implemented.

Subsection.Text: The company is not required to provide the prescribed person with the information referred to in paragraph (9)(h) if it is not available on the day on which the notice is given but must provide that information as soon as it is available.
For the purposes of subsection 10.1(1) of the Act, a person, other than the first retail purchaser, who obtained a restraint system or booster seat from a company is a prescribed person.
A notice of non-compliance that is required to be given under subsection 10.1(1) of the Act must be in writing, in either paper or electronic form, and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a notice given to the Minister, be in either official language; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a notice given to the current owner of the restraint system or booster seat or a prescribed person,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: be in the person’s official language of choice, if it is known, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: be in both official languages.

Subsection.Text: Unless the notice of non-compliance contains a statement under subparagraph (4)(k)(i), a company must give the notice of non-compliance to the current owner of the restraint system or booster seat and to the prescribed person as soon as feasible, but not later than 60 days after the day on which the company gives the notice of non-compliance to the Minister.

If the notice of non-compliance contains a statement under subparagraph (4)(k)(i) and the Minister advises the company that the Minister has determined that the non-compliance is not inconsequential to safety, the company must give the notice of non-compliance to the current owner of the restraint system or booster seat and to the prescribed person as soon as feasible after the day on which the company receives the Minister’s determination, but not later than 60 days after that day.
A notice of non-compliance that is given to the Minister must contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the company’s name and its contact information for the purpose of correspondence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the manufacturer of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number, title or other identification that is assigned by the company to the notice;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for each restraint system or booster seat that may be non-compliant, the model name and number, the prescribed class of equipment and any other information that is necessary to permit its identification;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the period during which the restraint systems or booster seats were manufactured;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated number of restraint systems or booster seats that could potentially be non-compliant;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated percentage of the restraint systems or booster seats referred to in paragraph (f) that are non-compliant;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the non-compliance, including the applicable regulatory requirement, the causes and contributing factors, if known;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the systems or components of the restraint system or booster seat that may be affected by the non-compliance;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a chronology of the principal events that led to the determination of the non-compliance, including the test results, observations, inspections and any other relevant information;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: as the case may be,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement that the non-compliance is inconsequential to safety, including detailed information to support the statement, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the safety risk to persons arising from the non-compliance;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the corrective measures to be taken in respect of the non-compliance and how they are to be implemented;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: any precautions that may be taken to minimize the safety risk until the corrective measures are implemented; and

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated date on which the notice of non-compliance will be sent to the current owner of the restraint system or booster seat and the estimated date on which the notice of non-compliance will be sent to a prescribed person.

Subsection.Text: The company is not required to provide the Minister with the information referred to in paragraphs (4)(j), (l) and (m) if it is not available on the day on which the notice is given but must provide that information as soon as it is available.

The company is not required to provide the Minister with the information referred to in paragraph (4)(n) if the notice of non-compliance contains a statement under subparagraph (4)(k)(i), but if the Minister advises the company that the Minister has determined that the non-compliance is not inconsequential to safety, the company must provide that information within five working days after the day on which the company receives the Minister’s determination.
A notice of non-compliance that is given to the current owner of the restraint system or booster seat must contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the company’s name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the model name and number of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the following statements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: “This notice is sent to you in accordance with the requirements of the Motor Vehicle Safety Act.”, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: “This is to inform you that your restraint system or booster seat may be non-compliant with the requirements of the Motor Vehicle Restraint Systems and Booster Seats Safety Regulations and that the non-compliance could affect the safety of a person.”;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the number, title or other identification that is assigned by the company to the notice;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the motor vehicle safety recall number that is issued by the Department of Transport;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the non-compliance, including the causes;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the systems or components of the restraint system or booster seat that may be affected by the non-compliance;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: operating conditions or other factors that may cause a malfunction of the system or component of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the warning signs, if any, of any malfunction that could arise as a result of the non-compliance;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the safety risk to persons arising from the non-compliance, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the type of injury that may result from the non-compliance;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the corrective measures to be taken in respect of the non-compliance and how they are to be implemented, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a general description of the work involved,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the estimated time required in order to take the corrective measures,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement that the company will cover the costs of the corrective measures or an estimate of the cost of the corrective measures to the current owner of the restraint system or booster seat, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: information identifying the persons who can implement the corrective measures; and

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: any precautions that may be taken to minimize the safety risk until the corrective measures are implemented.

Subsection.Text: The company is not required to provide to the current owner the information referred to in paragraph (6)(l) if it is not available on the day on which the notice is given but must provide that information

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as it is available; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at the same time as the company provides the information required under subsection 10.4(1) of the Act.

Subsection.Text: The words “SAFETY”, “RECALL”, “RAPPEL” and “SÉCURITÉ” are required to be clearly visible

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the envelope, or through a window of the envelope, in upper case and in a font size that is larger than the one used for the recipient’s address, if the notice of non-compliance is given to the current owner in paper form; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the subject line of the communication, in upper case, if the notice of non-compliance is given to the current owner in electronic form.

Subsection.Text: A notice of non-compliance that is given to a prescribed person must contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the company’s name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for each restraint system or booster seat that may be non-compliant, the model name and number and any other information that is necessary to permit its identification;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number, title or other identification that is assigned by the company to the notice;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the motor vehicle safety recall number that is issued by the Department of Transport;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the non-compliance, including the causes;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: operating conditions or other factors that may cause a malfunction of the system or component of the restraint system or booster seat;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the safety risk to persons arising from the non-compliance, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the corrective measures to be taken in respect of the non-compliance and how they are to be implemented; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any precautions that may be taken to minimize the safety risk until the corrective measures are implemented.

Subsection.Text: The company is not required to provide to the prescribed person the information referred to in paragraph (9)(h) if it is not available on the day on which the notice is given but must provide that information as soon as it is available.

Section.MarginalNote: Initial report — notice to current owners

Subsection.Text: Within five working days after the day on which a company begins sending a notice of defect or non-compliance to current owners, the company must provide the Minister with a report containing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the notice;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a sample of the envelope used to mail the notice;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the company began sending notices;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the company finished, or expects to finish, sending notices; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the number of restraint systems or booster seats that are subject to the notice.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(b), a company is not required to provide a sample of the envelope if it uses an envelope that has previously been provided as a sample to the Minister and the report includes the date on which the sample was provided.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Initial report — notice to prescribed persons
Subsection.Text: Within five working days after the day on which a company begins sending a notice of defect or non-compliance to prescribed persons, the company must provide to the Minister a report containing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the notice; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if no notices are sent to current owners, the number of restraint systems or booster seats that are subject to the notice.

Subsection.Text: For a period of five years beginning on the 60th day after the day on which a company gives a notice to the Minister under subsection 10(1) or 10.1(1) of the Act, the company must provide the Minister, within five working days after the day on which they are sent to their recipients, a copy of any of the following communications, with the date on which they were sent to their recipients:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: communications sent to more than one current owner relating to the defect or non-compliance; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: communications sent to more than one prescribed person relating to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the information set out in subsection 110(9) or 110.01(9), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the defect or non-compliance.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 10.2 of the Act, a company that gives a notice of defect or non-compliance to a current owner or a prescribed person must provide the Minister with quarterly reports that contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the motor vehicle safety recall number that is issued by the Department of Transport;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number, title or other identification that is assigned by the company to the notice;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of restraint systems or booster seats that are subject to the notice, including the day on which the number was updated by the company;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the number of restraint systems or booster seats for which corrective measures have been taken, including those that required only an inspection, and the day on which that number was determined by the company; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a statement setting out the manner in which the company disposed of the defective parts, restraint systems or booster seats.

Subsection.Text: The company must provide the Minister with quarterly reports, in accordance with the following schedule, for a period of two years beginning on the 60th day after the day on which the company gives a notice to the Minister under subsection 10(1) or 10.1(1) of the Act:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the first calendar quarter, from January 1 through March 31, on or before April 30;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the second calendar quarter, from April 1 through June 30, on or before July 30;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for the third calendar quarter, from July 1 through September 30, on or before October 30; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for the fourth calendar quarter, from October 1 through December 31, on or before January 30 of the following year.

Subsection.Text: A company that gives a notice of defect or non-compliance to the Minister under subsection 10(1) or 10.1(1) of the Act must publish the following information, in both official languages, on the website that the company uses to communicate information directed at the Canadian market:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the notice was given to the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the model name and number of the restraint system or booster seat referred to in the notice and any other information that is necessary to permit its identification;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number, title or other identification that is assigned by the company to the notice;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the motor vehicle safety recall number that is issued by the Department of Transport;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the nature of the defect, including the causes of the defect, and its location, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the non-compliance, including the causes;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the safety risk to persons arising from the defect or non-compliance;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the type of injury that may result from the defect or non-compliance;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the corrective measures to be taken in respect of the defect or non-compliance and how they are to be implemented;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any precautions that may be taken to minimize the safety risk until the corrective measures are implemented;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a statement that the parts and facilities that are necessary to correct the defect or non-compliance are available or, if they are not, the earliest date by which they are expected to be available;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, a statement indicating that information in respect of notices that are given before a specified date is not available on the website and how to obtain the information;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: on each web page displaying the information referred to in paragraphs (a) to (k), instructions on how to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: contact the company concerning any questions related to the notice,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: report a safety concern relating to a restraint system or booster seat, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: inform the company of a transfer of ownership of a restraint system or booster seat or a change of address; and

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the information was last updated on each web page displaying the information referred to in paragraphs (a) to (k).

Subsection.Text: The company must publish the information referred to in subsection (1) as soon as feasible, but not later than 60 days after the day on which the company gives the notice to the Minister, and must update the information within seven days after the day on which there is any change to it.

Despite subsection (2), if the information referred to in paragraph (1)(d), (h) or (j) is not available on the day on which it is to be published, the company must publish the information within seven days after the day on which it becomes available.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Minimum period of availability of information
Subsection.Text: The company must ensure that the information referred to in subsection (1) remains displayed on the website for at least 10 years beginning on the day on which the company gives the notice of defect or non-compliance to the Minister.
The information referred to in subparagraphs (1)(l)(i) to (iii) may be made available by way of a hyperlink.
The company must ensure that the information referred to in subsection (1) is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: available free of charge;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: accessible without the user having to register or enter any information; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: displayed either directly on the website’s home page or made available by way of a hyperlink that contains the word “Recall” or “Recalls” and that is prominently displayed on that home page.

Subsection.Text: A company is not required to meet the requirements of this section if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements have been met by another company that manufactured, sold or imported the restraint system or booster seat; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the company does not have a website to communicate information directed at the Canadian market.

Subsection.Text: This section applies to a company beginning on the first anniversary of the day on which this section comes into force.

Section.Text: In this Part, Test Method 213 means Test Method 213 — Child Restraint Systems (May 2012), published by the Department of Transport.
Every child restraint system must, when the anthropomorphic test device is positioned in the restraint system in accordance with subsection 4.4.2 or 4.5.2 of Test Method 213,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: restrain the upper torso by means of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a forward-facing restraint system,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: belts passing over each shoulder, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: a fixed or movable surface that conforms to the requirements of section 211, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a rear-facing restraint system, belts passing over each shoulder;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: restrain the lower torso by means of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a pelvic restraint making an angle of at least 45° but not more than 90° with the seating surface of the restraint system at the pelvic restraint attachment points, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a fixed or movable surface that conforms to the requirements of section 211; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a forward-facing restraint system, restrain the crotch by means of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a crotch belt that is connectable to the pelvic restraint or to any other device used to restrain the lower torso, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a fixed or movable surface that conforms to the requirements of section 211.

Section.MarginalNote: Means of securing forward-facing child restraint system

Subsection.Text: Every forward-facing child restraint system must be designed to be secured to a vehicle

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by means of a vehicle seat belt together with the tether strap provided with the restraint system, without using any other means of attachment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by means of a lower connector system together with the tether strap provided with the restraint system, without using any other means of attachment.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), every rear-facing child restraint system must be designed to be secured to a vehicle

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by means of a vehicle seat belt, without using any other means of attachment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by means of a lower connector system, without using any other means of attachment.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Rear-facing child restraint system with tether strap
Subsection.Text: If a rear-facing child restraint system is equipped with a tether strap and the manufacturer recommends its use, the restraint system must be designed to be secured to a vehicle

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by means of the tether strap together with a vehicle seat belt, without using any other means of attachment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by means of the tether strap together with a lower connector system, without using any other means of attachment.

Section.MarginalNote: Belts and movable surfaces designed to restrain a child
Section.Text: Every belt or movable surface that is part of a child restraint system and that is designed to restrain a child must be adjustable to snugly fit a child whose mass and height are within the ranges indicated in the statement referred to in paragraph 218(1)(d), when the child is positioned in the restraint system in accordance with the instructions referred to in paragraph 220(1)(c) and the restraint system is adjusted in accordance with the instructions referred to in paragraph 220(1)(d).

Every child restraint system must provide a clear, audible indication when each connector in a lower connector system is securely attached to the lower universal anchorage system or a clear, visual indication that each connector is securely attached to the lower universal anchorage system.
Every child restraint system must be constructed only of materials that conform to the requirements of TSD 302.

Every belt buckle and related piece of adjustment hardware and every tether strap attachment and related piece of adjustment hardware that are part of a child restraint system must conform to the requirements of S4.3(a)(2) and (b) of TSD 209.
Every belt buckle that is fitted on a belt designed to restrain a child in a child restraint system must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under the conditions set out in section 3 of Test Method 213,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: not release when any force of less than 40 N is applied, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: release when a force of at least 40 N but not more than 62 N is applied;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: under the conditions set out in section 5 of Test Method 213, release when a force of not more than 71 N is applied;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: conform to the requirements of S4.3(d)(2) of TSD 209, except that the surface area of a belt buckle designed for push-button application must be at least 385 mm2;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: conform to the requirements of S4.3(g) of TSD 209; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: not release during the dynamic tests specified in section 4 of Test Method 213.

Section.Text: Any webbing that is designed to secure a child restraint system to a user-ready tether anchorage or to a lower universal anchorage system, or to restrain a child within the restraint system, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when tested in accordance with S5.1(b) of TSD 209, before being tested for resistance to abrasion as specified in S5.1(d) or S5.3(c) of TSD 209, for resistance to light as specified in S5.1(e) of TSD 209 or for resistance to micro-organisms as specified in S5.1(f) of TSD 209, have a breaking strength of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: at least 15 000 N, in the case of webbing designed to secure the restraint system to the user-ready tether anchorage or to the lower universal anchorage system, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: at least 11 000 N, in the case of webbing designed to restrain a child within the restraint system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when tested in accordance with S5.1(b) of TSD 209, after being tested for resistance to abrasion as specified in S5.1(d) or S5.3(c) of TSD 209, have a breaking strength of at least 75% of its initial breaking strength;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: conform to the requirements respecting breaking strength set out in S4.2(e) and (f) of TSD 209; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if contactable by the torso when the restraint system is tested in accordance with section 4 of Test Method 213, have a width of not less than 38 mm, measured as specified in S5.1(a) of TSD 209.

Section.Text: Every child restraint system must provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the support of the child’s back, a continuous surface that is flat or concave and has an area of not less than 54 800 mm2; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the support of the sides of the child’s torso, continuous surfaces that are flat or concave and have an area of not less than 30 500 mm2 each.

Section.Text: A child restraint system must not have any surface directly in front of the child, unless the surface is designed to limit the forward movement of the child.

Every horizontal cross-section of a surface of a child restraint system that is designed to limit the forward movement of a child must be flat or concave, and every vertical longitudinal cross-section of that surface must be flat or convex with a radius of curvature of the underlying structure of not less than 50 mm.
Any rigid structural element underlying a contactable surface of a child restraint system must not have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a protrusion, with any padding or flexible overlay material removed, of more than 9.5 mm; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an exposed edge with a radius of less than 6.4 mm.

Section.Text: Every surface of a child restraint system that is contactable by the head of an anthropomorphic test device positioned in the restraint system in accordance with subsection 4.4.2 or 4.5.2 of Test Method 213 must be covered with slow-recovery, energy-absorbing material that, when tested in accordance with section 6 of Test Method 213, has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a resistance of not less than 4 kPa but not more than 70 kPa at 25% of compression-deflection resistance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a thickness of not less than 12 mm, if the material has a resistance of not less than 12 kPa but not more than 70 kPa at 25% of compression-deflection resistance; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a thickness of not less than 19 mm, if the material has a resistance of not less than 4 kPa but less than 12 kPa at 25% of compression-deflection resistance.

Section.Text: A child restraint system that is subjected to an inversion test in accordance with section 7 of Test Method 213 must not fall out of the aircraft passenger seat belt, and the anthropomorphic test device must not fall out of the restraint system, at any time during the rotation or three-second immobilisation period referred to in that section.

Subsection.Text: A child restraint system that is subjected to a dynamic test in accordance with section 4 of Test Method 213 must, when in any adjustment position for which there is no warning under subparagraph 218(1)(e)(iii),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: exhibit no complete separation of any load-bearing structural element, and no partial separation exposing a surface with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a protrusion of more than 9.5 mm, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a radius of less than 6.4 mm;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: remain in the same adjustment position during the test as it was in immediately before the test began;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of a restraint system tested with the anthropomorphic test device specified in subpart S, part 572, chapter V, title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States (revised as of October 1, 2012), limit the resultant acceleration at the location of the accelerometer mounted in the upper thorax of the anthropomorphic test device to not more than 60 g, except for intervals of not more than 3 ms;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of a restraint system tested with the anthropomorphic test device specified in subpart S, part 572, chapter V, title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States (revised as of October 1, 2012), limit the resultant acceleration of the centre of gravity of the head of the anthropomorphic test device during the movement of the head towards the front of the vehicle to not more than 80 g, except for intervals of not more than 3 ms, unless it is established that any resultant acceleration above 80 g is caused by another part of the anthropomorphic test device striking its head;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection 216(2), limit the movement of the head of the anthropomorphic test device towards the rear of the restraint system by means of a continuous seat back that is an integral part of the restraint system; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection 216(2), limit the rotation of the head of the anthropomorphic test device towards the rear of the restraint system, in its midsagittal plane, by means of a continuous seat back that is an integral part of the restraint system, so that the angle between the head and the torso is at no time during the test more than 45° as compared to the angle between the head and the torso prior to the test.

Subsection.Text: The continuous seat back referred to in paragraphs (1)(e) and (f) must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a height

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: of at least 500 mm, in the case of a child restraint system recommended by the manufacturer for use by a child whose mass is 18 kg or less, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: of at least 560 mm, in the case of a child restraint system recommended by the manufacturer for use by a child whose mass is more than 18 kg; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a width of at least 200 mm, measured in the horizontal plane at the height specified in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: The height referred to in paragraph (2)(a) must be measured in a plane parallel to the surface of the seat back of the child restraint system and orthogonal to the vertical longitudinal plane passing through the longitudinal centreline of the restraint system, from the lowest point of the restraint system’s seating surface that is contacted by the buttocks of the seated anthropomorphic test device.

Despite paragraph (2)(b), if the child restraint system provides surfaces for the support of the sides of the torso, and those surfaces extend at least 100 mm forward from the padded surface of the portion of the restraint system provided for the support of the head of the anthropomorphic test device, the restraint system may have a continuous seat back width of not less than 150 mm, measured in the horizontal plane at the height referred to in paragraph (2)(a).

Every belt that is part of a child restraint system and that is designed to restrain a child in the restraint system must not, when subjected to a dynamic test in accordance with section 4 of Test Method 213, impose on the anthropomorphic test device any loads that result from the mass of the restraint system or the mass of the seat back of the standard seat assembly.

A forward-facing child restraint system that is subjected to a dynamic test in accordance with section 4 of Test Method 213 must not, when in any adjustment position for which there is no warning under subparagraph 218(1)(e)(iii),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of a restraint system tested with the anthropomorphic test device specified in subpart S, part 572, chapter V, title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States (revised as of October 1, 2012), allow any portion of the head of the anthropomorphic test device to pass through the vertical transverse plane — shown as the forward excursion limit in Figures 5 and 6 of Schedule 7 — that is 720 mm forward of the Z point on the standard seat assembly, measured along the SORL;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of a restraint system tested with the anthropomorphic test device specified in subpart S, part 572, chapter V, title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States (revised as of October 1, 2012), allow either knee pivot point to pass through the vertical transverse plane — shown as the forward excursion limit in Figures 5 and 6 of Schedule 7 — that is 915 mm forward of the Z point on the standard seat assembly, measured along the SORL; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: allow the angle between the restraint system’s back support surface and seating surface to be less than 45° at the completion of the test.

Subsection.Text: A forward-facing child restraint system is not required to conform to the requirements of paragraphs 215(1)(e) and (f) if the target point located on either side of the head of the heaviest of the anthropomorphic test devices used in the dynamic test — other than an anthropomorphic test device specified in subpart I, N or S, part 572, chapter V, title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States (revised as of October 1, 2012) — and located on the transverse axis passing through the centre of mass of the device’s head and perpendicular to the head’s midsagittal plane is below a horizontal plane tangent to the top of the standard seat assembly when the anthropomorphic test device is positioned in the restraint system in accordance with subsection 4.4.2 or 4.5.2 of Test Method 213 and the restraint system is installed on the standard seat assembly in accordance with subsection 4.4.1 or 4.5.1 of Test Method 213.

Section.Text: A rear-facing child restraint system that is subjected to a dynamic test in accordance with section 4 of Test Method 213 must, when in any adjustment position for which there is no warning under subparagraph 218(1)(e)(iii),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: retain the torso of the anthropomorphic test device within the restraint system, and not allow any portion of the target points on either side of the device’s head, located on the transverse axis passing through the centre of mass of the device’s head and perpendicular to the head’s midsagittal plane, to pass at any time, during or immediately after the test, either through the transverse orthogonal planes formed by the extension of the seat back frontal surface plane of the restraint system and by the plane that passes through the uppermost point of the restraint system, as shown in Figure 7 of Schedule 7, or through the vertical transverse plane passing through point X on the standard seat assembly, as shown in Figure 8 of Schedule 7; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: not allow the angle between the vertical and the back and head support surface, measured 240 mm above the seating surface, to be more than 70° at any time during the test.

Subsection.Text: Every child restraint system must have stitched onto it, indelibly moulded into or onto it, or indelibly printed on a label affixed to it in a permanent manner, the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the company that manufactured, imported or sold the restraint system and the address of its principal place of business;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the model name and number of the restraint system;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date of manufacture of the restraint system, as shown in Schedule 5, with the year, month and day above the corresponding wording in both official languages;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a statement indicating — in units based on the International System of Units followed by the corresponding imperial units in parentheses — the mass and height range of the children for whom the manufacturer recommends the restraint system when it is used in a forward-facing and, where applicable, a rear-facing position;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a warning indicating

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: if the restraint system can be used in a forward-facing position, that it must be secured to the vehicle as shown in the installation instructions by means of the tether strap provided with the restraint system and by either of the following means:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: a lower connector system, if the restraint system is installed in a seating position that is equipped with a lower universal anchorage system, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: a vehicle seat belt, if the restraint system is installed in a seating position that is not equipped with a lower universal anchorage system,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the restraint system can be used in a rear-facing position, that it must be secured to the vehicle as shown in the installation instructions by either of the following means and, if the restraint system is equipped with a tether strap and the manufacturer recommends its use, by means of the tether strap:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: a lower connector system, if the restraint system is installed in a seating position that is equipped with a lower universal anchorage system, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: a vehicle seat belt, if the restraint system is installed in a seating position that is not equipped with a lower universal anchorage system,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the restraint system is not designed to be used at certain adjustment positions, that those adjustment positions must not be used,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: if the restraint system is equipped with belts for restraining a child, that the belts must be snugly adjusted around the child, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: if the restraint system is equipped with a fixed or movable surface for restraining the child and also requires the use of belts to restrain the child, that the surface alone is not sufficient to restrain the child;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if the restraint system can be used in a forward-facing position, an installation diagram that shows the restraint system

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: installed in a forward-facing position as recommended by the manufacturer in a seating position that is equipped only with a lap belt, and secured to the vehicle by means of the belt and by means of the tether strap,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: installed in a forward-facing position as recommended by the manufacturer in a seating position that is equipped only with a continuous-loop lap and shoulder belt, and secured to the vehicle by means of the belt and by means of the tether strap, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: installed in a forward-facing position as recommended by the manufacturer in a seating position that is equipped with a lower universal anchorage system, and secured to the vehicle by means of a lower connector system and by means of the tether strap; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if the restraint system can be used in a rear-facing position, an installation diagram that shows the restraint system

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: installed in a rear-facing position as recommended by the manufacturer in a seating position that is equipped only with a lap belt, and secured to the vehicle by means of the belt and, if the restraint system is equipped with a tether strap and the manufacturer recommends its use, by means of the tether strap,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: installed in a rear-facing position as recommended by the manufacturer in a seating position that is equipped only with a continuous-loop lap and shoulder belt, and secured to the vehicle by means of the belt and, if the restraint system is equipped with a tether strap and the manufacturer recommends its use, by means of the tether strap, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: installed in a rear-facing position as recommended by the manufacturer in a seating position that is equipped with a lower universal anchorage system, and secured to the vehicle by means of a lower connector system and, if the restraint system is equipped with a tether strap and the manufacturer recommends its use, by means of the tether strap.

Subsection.Text: The information referred to in subsection (1) must be in both official languages and in characters of at least 10 points, except for the words “year/année”, “month/mois” and “day/jour” under the date of manufacture, which may be in characters of at least 8 points.
The information referred to in paragraphs (1)(d) to (g) must be fully visible at all times, even when the restraint system is occupied.
Every child restraint system that can be used in a rear-facing position must bear the air bag warning label shown in Schedule 6, and the label must conform to the requirements of that schedule.
The label referred to in subsection (1) must be affixed in a permanent manner at either of the following locations and be fully visible to a person installing the restraint system:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the side of the restraint system that will face the right front passenger door when the restraint system is facing rearward; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at the location where the child’s head would rest or adjacent to that location.

Subsection.Text: Every child restraint system must be accompanied by printed instructions, in both official languages, that set out a step-by-step procedure, including diagrams, for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: installing and securing the restraint system in a vehicle;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: installing the restraint system in an aircraft passenger seat referred to in subsection 2.1.2 of Test Method 213;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: positioning a child in the restraint system; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: adjusting every part of the restraint system that is designed to restrain the child.

Subsection.Text: The instructions referred to in paragraph (1)(a) must state that the restraint system, even when unoccupied, must be firmly secured to the vehicle.
The instructions must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: specify the classes of vehicles, the seating positions and the types of vehicle seat belts with which the restraint system may or may not be used;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: specify that the restraint system may be used with a lower universal anchorage system; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: explain the primary consequences of not following the warnings appearing on the restraint system.

Subsection.Text: Every child restraint system must have a place for the storage of instructions.

Section.Text: In this Part, Test Method 213.1 means Test Method 213.1 — Infant Restraint Systems (May 2012), published by the Department of Transport.

Section.MarginalNote: Restraint system designed to face the rear
Section.Text: Every infant restraint system must be designed to face the rear of the vehicle.
Every infant restraint system must, when the anthropomorphic test device is positioned in the restraint system in accordance with subsection 4.5.2 or 4.6.2 of Test Method 213.1,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: restrain the upper torso by means of belts passing over each shoulder; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: restrain the lower torso.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), every infant restraint system must be designed to be secured to a vehicle

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by means of a vehicle seat belt in such a manner that the belt will not impose directly on the infant any loads that result from the mass of the restraint system, and without using any other means of attachment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by means of a lower connector system, without using any other means of attachment.

Subsection.Text: If an infant restraint system is equipped with a tether strap and the manufacturer recommends its use, the restraint system must be designed to be secured to a vehicle

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by means of the tether strap together with a vehicle seat belt in such a manner that the belt will not impose directly on the infant any loads that result from the mass of the restraint system, and without using any other means of attachment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by means of the tether strap together with a lower connector system, without using any other means of attachment.

Section.Text: If an infant restraint system is manufactured with a removable base and the seating component of the restraint system is designed to be used in a vehicle with or without the base, the restraint system must be equipped with a lower connector system on the base.

Section.MarginalNote: Part designed to restrain an infant
Section.Text: Every part of an infant restraint system that is designed to restrain an infant must be adjustable to snugly fit an infant whose mass and height are within the ranges indicated in the statement referred to in paragraph 316(1)(d), when the infant is positioned in the restraint system in accordance with the instructions referred to in paragraph 318(1)(c) and the restraint system is adjusted in accordance with the instructions referred to in paragraph 318(1)(d).

Every infant restraint system must provide a clear, audible indication when each connector in a lower connector system is securely attached to the lower universal anchorage system or a clear, visual indication that each connector is securely attached to the lower universal anchorage system.
Every infant restraint system must be constructed only of materials that conform to the requirements of TSD 302.

Every belt buckle and related piece of adjustment hardware and every tether strap attachment and related piece of adjustment hardware that are part of an infant restraint system must conform to the requirements of S4.3(a)(2) and (b) of TSD 209.
Every belt buckle that is fitted on a belt designed to restrain an infant in an infant restraint system must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under the conditions set out in section 3 of Test Method 213.1,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: not release when any force of less than 40 N is applied, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: release when a force of at least 40 N but not more than 62 N is applied;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: under the conditions set out in section 5 of Test Method 213.1, release when a force of not more than 71 N is applied;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: conform to the requirements of S4.3(d)(2) of TSD 209, except that the surface area of a belt buckle designed for push-button application must be at least 385 mm2;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: conform to the requirements of S4.3(g) of TSD 209; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: not release during the dynamic tests specified in section 4 of Test Method 213.1.

Section.Text: Any webbing that is designed to secure an infant restraint system to a user-ready tether anchorage or to a lower universal anchorage system, or to restrain an infant within the restraint system, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when tested in accordance with S5.1(b) of TSD 209, before being tested for resistance to abrasion as specified in S5.1(d) or S5.3(c) of TSD 209, for resistance to light as specified in S5.1(e) of TSD 209 or for resistance to micro-organisms as specified in S5.1(f) of TSD 209, have a breaking strength of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: at least 15 000 N in the case of webbing designed to secure the restraint system to the user-ready tether anchorage or to the lower universal anchorage system, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: at least 11 000 N in the case of webbing designed to restrain an infant within the restraint system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when tested in accordance with S5.1(b) of TSD 209, after being tested for resistance to abrasion as specified in S5.1(d) or S5.3(c) of TSD 209, have a breaking strength of at least 75% of its initial breaking strength;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: conform to the requirements respecting breaking strength set out in S4.2(e) and (f) of TSD 209; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if contactable by the torso when the restraint system is tested in accordance with section 4 of Test Method 213.1, have a width of not less than 38 mm, measured as specified in S5.1(a) of TSD 209.

Section.Text: Every infant restraint system must provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the support of the infant’s back, a continuous surface that is flat or concave and has an area of not less than 54 800 mm2; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the support of the sides of the infant’s torso, continuous surfaces that are flat or concave and have an area of not less than 30 500 mm2 each.

Section.Text: Any rigid structural element underlying a contactable surface of an infant restraint system must not have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a protrusion, with any padding or flexible overlay material removed, of more than 9.5 mm; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an exposed edge with a radius of less than 6.4 mm.

Section.Text: Every surface of an infant restraint system that is contactable by the head of an anthropomorphic test device positioned in the restraint system in accordance with subsection 4.5.2 or 4.6.2 of Test Method 213.1 must be covered with slow-recovery, energy-absorbing material that, when tested in accordance with section 6 of Test Method 213.1, has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a resistance of not less than 4 kPa but not more than 70 kPa at 25% of compression-deflection resistance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a thickness of not less than 12 mm, if the material has a resistance of not less than 12 kPa but not more than 70 kPa at 25% of compression-deflection resistance; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a thickness of not less than 19 mm, if the material has a resistance of not less than 4 kPa but less than 12 kPa at 25% of compression-deflection resistance.

Section.Text: An infant restraint system that is subjected to an inversion test in accordance with section 7 of Test Method 213.1 must not fall out of the aircraft passenger seat belt, and the anthropomorphic test device must not fall out of the restraint system, at any time during the rotation or three-second immobilization period referred to in that section.

Subsection.Text: An infant restraint system that is subjected to a dynamic test in accordance with section 4 of Test Method 213.1 must, if the adjustment position of each component of the restraint system is in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: exhibit no complete separation of any load-bearing structural element, and no partial separation exposing a surface with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a protrusion of more than 9.5 mm, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a radius of less than 6.4 mm;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: remain in the same adjustment position during the test as it was in immediately before the test began, except that, if the restraint system has a means of automatically repositioning the seating surface to allow the anthropomorphic test device to move from a reclined position to a more upright position and back to a reclined position during the test, the seating surface does not have to remain in the same adjustment position during the test as it was in immediately before the test began;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: limit the resultant acceleration at the location of the accelerometer mounted in the upper thorax of the anthropomorphic test device to not more than 60 g, except for intervals of not more than 3 ms;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
